title: Elton John brands the late Michael Jackson 'mentally ill' and 'disturbing' in candid autobiography
text:

Sir Elton John has branded the late Michael Jackson "mentally ill" and "disturbing to be around" in his sensational new memoir.

The signer, 72, explained that he had been friendly with the Thriller hitmaker in his early career but saw how he changed as his fame grew.

They met when Michael was just thirteen, with Elton describing him as "just the most adorable kid you could imagine".

Elton wrote: "But at some point in the intervening years, he started sequestering himself away from the world, and away from reality the way Elvis Presley did."

He added: "God knows what was going on in his head, and God knows what prescription drugs he was being pumped full of, but every time I saw him in his later years I came away thinking the poor guy had totally lost his marbles."

(Image: Adam Scull/REX/Shutterstock)

Elton continued: "I don’t mean that in the light-hearted way. He was genuinely mentally ill, a disturbing person to be around."

He invited Jackson to one of his parties, where he claims he wandered off and was found playing with the housekeeper's son.

Elton said: "For whatever reason, he couldn't seem to cope with adult company at all."

(Image: Getty Images)

Jackson was accused of sexually abusing James Safechuck and Wade Robson in controversial documentary Leaving Neverland: Michael Jackson & Me.

The Jackson estate has furiously denied claims he sexually assaulted the young boys he befriended

Elton has made a string of revelations about his own private life in his new memoir.

(Image: WireImage)

He's spoken out about his relationship with his late mother and revealed that she would have struggled with his children.

Elton's mum, Sheila Farebrother, never met his two sons, eight-year-old Zachary and Elijah, six, who he shares with husband David Furnish.

He said: "She never liked David. She never liked anybody. She never asked to see the children. But I’m glad they didn’t meet her, because she would have criticised them, like she criticised me.
description: Sir Elton said he had been friendly with the Thriller hitmaker in his early career but saw how fame changed him
